content:
Male and female ducks usually share the responsibilities of raising their young, although the exact division of labor can vary depending on the species and individual circumstances.

In most duck species, the female is the primary caregiver during the incubation period, which lasts from the time the eggs are laid until they hatch. During this time, the female will spend most of her time on the nest, keeping the eggs warm and turning them over periodically to ensure that they develop properly.

Once the ducklings hatch, both parents will be involved in caring for them. Typically, the female will lead the ducklings to the nearest body of water, where they will begin to learn how to swim, find food, and avoid predators. The male will generally stay nearby to help defend the family against predators, although he may also leave periodically to forage for food.

Both parents will also be involved in teaching the ducklings how to feed themselves. They will lead the ducklings to areas where they can find food and may even demonstrate how to catch insects or other small prey.

Overall, while the female may take on more of the initial caregiving duties, both parents are essential to the survival of the young and will work together to ensure their offspring's success.
